Unit or Neutral Element

An element $e \in M$ is called a unit element or a neutral element with respect to the law of composition on $M$ if $ea = a = ae$ holds for all $a \in M$. Such a unit element $e$ is uniquely determined by its defining property; it is usually denoted as 1.
Ring

A ring (admitting a unit element) is a set R together with two laws of composition written as addition '+' and multiplication '.' such that: (i) R is a commutative group with respect to addition. (ii) R is a monoid with respect to multiplication, i.e., the multiplication is associative, and there exists a unit element in R. (iii) The distributive laws hold, i.e., (a+b) 
cdot c=a 
cdot c+b 
cdot c, and c 
cdot(a+b)=c 
cdot a+c 
cdot b for all a, b, c in R.
Zero Ring
The zero ring is a ring where the unit element of addition (0) and the unit element of multiplication (1) are the same, i.e., 1=0. It consists of a single element 0.
System of Generators of an Ideal

Let $\mathfrak{a}$ be an ideal of a ring $R$. A family $\left(a_{i}\right)_{i \in I}$ of elements in $\mathfrak{a}$ is called a system of generators of $\mathfrak{a}$ if $\mathfrak{a}=\sum_{i \in I} R a_{i}$, i.e., if $\mathfrak{a}$ coincides with the ideal generated by the family $\left(a_{i}\right)_{i \in I}$.
Kernel of a Ring Homomorphism
Let $\varphi: R \longrightarrow R'$ be a ring homomorphism. The kernel of $\varphi$, denoted $\operatorname{ker} \varphi$, is defined as $\{a \in R ; \varphi(a)=0\}$, which is an ideal in $R$.
System of generators
A family (x_i)_{i in I} of elements of an A-module M is called a system of generators of M if M = sum_{i in I} A x_i.
Subfield
A subring $T$ of a field $K$ is called a subfield if $T$ is a field itself.
Ring Homomorphism of Finite Type

A ring homomorphism $\varphi: A \longrightarrow B$ is of finite type if there exists an epimorphism $\Phi: A[X_{1}, \ldots, X_{n}] \longrightarrow B$ from a polynomial ring in finitely many variables over $A$ to $B$ that extends $\varphi$. Alternatively, it can be characterized by the existence of elements $x_{1}, \ldots, x_{n} \in B$ such that $B=\varphi(A)[x_{1}, \ldots, x_{n}]$.
Algebraic Closure of Finite Field

An algebraic closure $\\[\overline{\mathbb{F}}_p\]$ of a finite field $\\[\mathbb{F}_p\]$ is a field that contains $\\[\mathbb{F}_p\]$ and all its algebraic extensions. It is used to view the fields $\\[\mathbb{F}_{p^n}\]$ as subfields.
Separable extension
An extension $L / K$ is called separable if it does not contain any inseparable algebraic elements over $K$.
Normalizer
Let $G$ be a group and $S \subset G$ a subset. The normalizer of $S$ in $G$ is given by $N_{S}=\{x \in G ; x S=S x\}$.
Tensor
A tensor is a multi-dimensional array, generalizing the concept of a scalar, vector and matrix.
Inheritance_Analysis

Generalization_Specialization_Relationsh.Explanation: A Zero Ring is a specialization of a Ring where the unit element of addition (0) and the unit element of multiplication (1) are the same, i.e., 1=0. This means it inherits all properties of a Ring but with the additional constraint that 1=0.
